newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish shares climb on selective demand.
newsitem.headline: Turkish shares climb on selective demand.

text.p: Turkish shares rose by 1.47 percent on Wednesday amid selective demand and improved market mood, brokers said.
The IMKB-100 stood at 64,302.67, up 932.98 points from Tuesday. Gains so far this week have totalled 3.12 percent. Daily volume rose to 7.8 trillion lira from Tuesday's 5.0 trillion.

"The market pierced resistance at 63,500 and 64,000 today amid demand for state shares. The market can rise to 65,000 tomorrow but there may be profit-taking sales after that," said Cenk Akyoldas from Yatirim Finansman.
"I think the buying came in the afternoon because share prices are cheap and there was nothing to spoil market mood," he added.
Brokers said buying in state-sector shares towards the end of the session had spilled over to the rest of the market, dragging the index higher.

They said there was still no fresh cash entry to the market in the lack of fresh expectations or market-moving news but they said cheaper prices after last week's 4.16 percent drop spurred selective activity.
The session's most active shares were those of the utility Cukurova Elektrik which gained 1,000 lira to 70,000. Shares of Aktas Elektrik, also a utility, also gained 15,000 lira to 465,000.
The 85-share industrial index rose by 1.22 percent to 71,185.61 and the 15-share financial index surged by 2.14 percent to 55,623.47.
Of the 217 shares traded, gainers outdid losers by 118 to 45 and 54 shares were stable.
